Award.AwardTitle: Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Chicago's Center for Elementary Mathematics and Science Education (CEMSE) is pursuing this EAGER project, "Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula," to help two of the groups that are developing curricula for the new Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (AP CSP) course prepare their materials for broad use. The two curricula -- both developed with NSF support -- are Mobile CSP (developed at Trinity College) and Thriving in Our Digital World (developed by the University of Texas at Austin).

The proposed work will focus on six areas that are critical for successful scaling of the curricula: usability, marketability, sustainability, robustness, standards labeling, and clarity about critical features. Researchers and curriculum developers at CEMSE will collaborate with the AP CSP curriculum developers to analyze their programs' strengths and weaknesses in these six areas and to develop templates, ancillaries, correlations, overviews, teacher's editions, and other assets that will make the curricula maximally useful and appealing to teachers across the nation. The work will provide a model for curriculum development for other CS courses, and may well provide insights into possible improvements to the CS Principles course framework itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula” (award # 1547051) began in July 2015 and ended in December 2016. The project aimed to improve two sets of instructional materials designed for the College Board’s new “Computer Science Principles” Advanced Placement course. Researchers, curriculum developers, and others at UChicago STEM Education worked with the creators of Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles (formerly Thriving in Our Digital World) to make their materials more usable for teachers, more effective for students, and more financially sustainable.

 

In order to accomplish these goals, UChicago STEM Education carried out a series of efforts that focused on usability, marketability, and sustainability. Curriculum designers at UChicago STEM Education analyzed sample student and teacher materials from the Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles curriculums and designed prototypes and templates that could be used to create more usable and effective materials. UChicago STEM Education staff also advised the Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles project leaders about marketing and professional development. All reports and other products that resulted from these efforts were delivered to the Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles projects and were used to improve their instructional materials, marketing collateral, and professional development efforts.

 

Business planning was a significant portion of the project’s work. The economic environment for Mobile CSP, UTeach CS Principles, and other AP Computer Science Principles curriculums is challenging: The market for AP CSP instructional materials is relatively small; margins are thin, particularly with the increasing availability of open educational resources; there are a large number of competitors in the space; and funding requirements for maintaining the online materials and for updating and revising the courses are substantial. These challenges, along with the need for significant and expensive professional development to prepare teachers to teach the AP CSP course, make it difficult to sustain these projects over the long term. The Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula project engaged Lee Wilson of Headway Strategies Consulting to work with the Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles teams to analyze their current situations and to create financial models and strategic plans for sustaining their projects after their grant funding ends.

 

The Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula project advanced knowledge by providing an existence proof for a new model for the development of instructional materials, one that brings together content specialists and practitioners with experts in curriculum engineering and business consulting. The project thus validates a new approach to the development of instructional materials. The project has had a broad impact by helping to produce more usable, robust, and marketable versions of Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles, which we expect to be adopted and used widely, thus increasing enrollment in AP CSP and beyond.

 

Instructional materials have the potential to be very cost-effective interventions (Koedel, Li, Polikoff, Hardaway, & Wrabel, 2016), particularly for instruction in areas such as computer science where teachers and students may need more support. The creation of high quality instructional materials, however, requires large, well-funded teams working over long periods of time (Burkhardt & Schoenfeld, 2003). Unfortunately, such “curriculum engineering” teams are not common either in the publishing industry or in academia. The Expanding the Reach of AP CSP Curricula project aimed to address this problem by helping the Mobile CSP and UTeach CS Principles teams become both more skillful in the production of high-quality instructional materials and more savvy in devising sustainable business models.
